Machine learning and deep learning models have drastically improved their performance in various domains, but they still suffer from biases in the training data distribution. These biases cause a mismatch between the training and test data distributions, leading to poor generalization of the model on the test distribution. A common form of these biases appears when the size of different classes or groups is imbalanced. When class sizes are not balanced, the imbalanced dataset problem arises, where large classes can dominate the training process, resulting in a model with low accuracy on small classes. A severe form of this problem, appearing in many real-world big datasets with a large number of classes, is the long-tailed data distribution, where the data distribution is skewed. In this case, most of the data belongs to a few prevailing classes, while a huge number of classes are represented by a few samples. Weather-related datasets, which include real-time high temporal- or spatial-resolution satellite or radar image data, fall into this category. Critical incidents are rare in these datasets, making it difficult for machine learning models to detect and forecast these unusual events.

A generic idea to address these biases is to adapt the training distribution to the test distribution, either by resampling or assigning weights based on the training loss to create a cost-sensitive weighting scheme. However, relying solely on the training distribution has been shown to be inefficient. A new approach is to augment single-objective learning models with additional data-driven constraints to alleviate the effect of bias in training data. This involves creating a target dataset that resembles the desired properties of the test distribution and imposing it on the training process as an additional constraint.

Meta-learning introduces a coupled framework to interlace the hyperparameter tuning using a validation set with the training process to guide it. In this paper, we adopt the Targeted Meta-Learning framework, which employs a small target distribution and bilevel programming to model the multi-objective structure on both the training and target distributions. This framework has two levels: one dealing with the main training process and the other using a well-tuned target dataset to optimize the weights of each desired class or group in the dataset. We will show that this framework can overcome the biases in weather-related learning problems by applying it to detect bow echoes in radar data.

Targeted Meta-Learning is a learning process that involves learning the learning process itself. It is a common practice in the machine learning field and in meta-learning.
